title: 103_hr2328
content:
The Act titled "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is established for the purpose outlined in the Congressional findings. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to conserve natural and cultural resources by engaging young men and women in a Public Lands Corps. This provides education and work opportunities while benefiting the economy and environment through rehabilitation and restoration of public lands and Indian reservations. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to engage youth conservation corps in cost-effective rehabilitation and restoration work on public lands and Indian reservations, where federal agencies lack personnel for such tasks. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to perform conservation work on public and Indian lands in a cost-effective manner, expose youth to public service, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in natural and cultural resources among young individuals. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to expand educational opportunities by rewarding individuals who participate in national service with increased access to higher education or job training, and stimulate interest in conservation careers among young men and women by exposing them to conservation professionals in land managing agencies. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Corps" refers to the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" are lands owned or administered by the United States, and "qualified youth or conservation corps" are programs offering work for individuals aged 16-25 in natural or cultural resource settings. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any recognized group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. "Indian" denotes a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" are real properties owned by tribes. The term "State" refers to any State of the United States, including territories like the District of Columbia and Guam. "Conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" encompasses projects related to natural, cultural, and historic preservation. The term "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" includes projects for preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrollees must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. Enrollees are exempt from civil service laws. The Public Lands Corps allows young individuals aged 16-25 to enroll without regard to civil service laws. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to certain projects under this Act. The Public Lands Corps allows young individuals aged 16-25 to enroll in projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects that provide long-term benefits, instill a work ethic, are labor-intensive, can be initiated promptly, and offer educational opportunities. All projects must be consistent with land management laws and policies. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can provide necessary services and facilities for conservation programs on public or Indian lands. They may also establish and use conservation centers for these programs, and arrange for logistical support from military installations when feasible. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can establish conservation centers for programs on public or Indian lands. They may arrange logistical support from military installations, set health and safety standards, and enter contracts with State and local agencies for center management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program authorizes the placement of qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies for research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide, with a focus on diversity. The program aims to provide opportunities for underrepresented groups in these agencies. The Resource Assistant Program aims to increase diversity by recruiting college students and recent graduates from various backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. The program's dual purposes are to augment the agency's workforce and provide participants with exposure to potential conservation careers. Existing nonprofit organizations may also be utilized to fulfill program requirements. Nonprofit organizations can implement the Resource Assistant Program through existing organizations. Participating nonprofits must contribute 25% of the total costs for each intern recruited and placed by them. They are required to submit an annual report evaluating the program's scope, size, and quality to the land managing agency. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants. Living allowances and terms of service are provided to participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program. The living allowance cannot exceed the maximum established for participants in the national service program. Participants agree to a term of service determined by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, consistent with the national service program requirements. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program may receive educational benefits or awards. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. They may also receive forbearance in the collection of Stafford Loans. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistants program can request forbearance on Stafford Loans while serving, in accordance with regulations. SEC. 8. Nondisplacement requirements apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. Funding details. Cost Sharing:
- Interior and Agriculture Secretaries can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps.
- The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources.
- No cost sharing required for projects on Indian lands.
- Public Lands Corps projects can receive contributions from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency. The Public Lands Corps established under the Act can receive contributions from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency for project costs. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture are eligible to receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act without any cost-sharing requirements. Authorization of funds under U.S.C. 12501 and following for Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture without restrictions. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out the Act.
